sections.title: Generating Functions for $N_A^p(n)$ and $N_A^q(n)$, and Six ways to Convolution and Recurrence Identities
Asymptotic Estimate of $N_A^p(n)$ when $A$ is a Finite Set

theorem_statement:
\label{iden-1} Let $n$ be a positive integer and let $A$ be a set of positive integers. We have
(a)  \[ \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}N^p_A(n)x^n=\left(\prod_{a\in A}\frac{1}{1-x^a}\right)\left(\sum_{b\in A}\frac{x^b}{1-x^b}\right), \]
(b)  \[ N^p_A(n)=\sum_{k=0}^{n-1}p_A(k)\tau_A(n-k), \]
(c)  \[ \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}N^q_A(n)x^n=\left(\prod_{a\in A}(1+x^a)\right)\left(\sum_{b\in A}\frac{x^b}{1+x^b}\right), \]
(d)  \[ N^q_A(n)=\sum_{k=0}^{n-1}q_A(k)\tau_A^s(n-k). \]
generated_proof:
Definitions and conventions
- For a set A ⊆ ℕ and n ≥ 0:
  - p_A(n): number of (unrestricted) partitions of n with all parts in A, with p_A(0)=1.
  - q_A(n): number of partitions of n into distinct parts from A, with q_A(0)=1.
  - N_A^p(n): total number of parts, counted with multiplicity, across all A-restricted partitions of n; set N_A^p(0)=0.
  - N_A^q(n): total number of parts across all A-restricted distinct-part partitions of n; set N_A^q(0)=0.
  - τ_A(m): number of divisors d of m that lie in A; set τ_A(0)=0.
  - τ_A^s(m): signed divisor count τ_A^s(m)=∑_{d∈A, d|m}(-1)^{m/d-1}; set τ_A^s(0)=0.

All generating functions are formal power series in x (coefficients in ℤ or in ℤ[u]). For any A (possibly infinite), products ∏_{a∈A} with factors having constant term 1 are well-defined as formal power series, since for each fixed total degree only finitely many factors can contribute.

(a) Identity for N_A^p(n)
Introduce the bivariate generating function
F(u,x)=∏_{a∈A}(1−u x^a)^{-1} = ∑_{n,m≥0} p_A(n,m) u^m x^n,
where p_A(n,m) counts A-restricted partitions of n with exactly m parts. Then
N_A^p(n)=∑_{m≥0} m p_A(n,m) = [x^n] (∂/∂u F(u,x))|_{u=1}.
Using the product rule in the ring ℤ[[x]][u] and the usual logarithmic derivative,
∂/∂u F(u,x) = F(u,x) ∑_{b∈A} x^b/(1−u x^b).
Evaluating at u=1 gives
∂/∂u F(u,x)|_{u=1} = (∏_{a∈A} (1−x^a)^{-1}) (∑_{b∈A} x^b/(1−x^b)).
Extracting coefficients of x^n yields
∑_{n=1}^∞ N_A^p(n) x^n = (∏_{a∈A} (1−x^a)^{-1}) (∑_{b∈A} x^b/(1−x^b)),
which is (a). (The n=0 term is 0 on both sides.)

(b) Convolution formula for N_A^p(n)
Let G(x)=∑_{b∈A} x^b/(1−x^b) = ∑_{m≥1} c_m x^m. From G(x)=∑_{b∈A}∑_{j≥1} x^{jb}, one has
c_m = |{(b,j): b∈A, j≥1, jb=m}| = |{b∈A: b|m}| = τ_A(m).
By (a) and Cauchy product,
N_A^p(n) = [x^n] (∑_{k≥0} p_A(k) x^k)(∑_{m≥1} τ_A(m) x^m)
= ∑_{k=0}^{n} p_A(k) τ_A(n−k) = ∑_{k=0}^{n−1} p_A(k) τ_A(n−k),
since τ_A(0)=0. This is (b).

(c) Identity for N_A^q(n)
Define
H(u,x)=∏_{a∈A}(1+u x^a) = ∑_{n,m≥0} q_A(n,m) u^m x^n,
with q_A(n,m) counting A-restricted distinct-part partitions of n with exactly m parts. Then
N_A^q(n)=∑_{m≥0} m q_A(n,m) = [x^n] (∂/∂u H(u,x))|_{u=1}.
As before,
∂/∂u H(u,x) = H(u,x) ∑_{b∈A} x^b/(1+u x^b),
so
∂/∂u H(u,x)|_{u=1} = (∏_{a∈A} (1+x^a)) (∑_{b∈A} x^b/(1+x^b)).
Extracting coefficients gives (c).

(d) Convolution formula for N_A^q(n)
Expand
∑_{b∈A} x^b/(1+x^b) = ∑_{b∈A} ∑_{j≥1} (−1)^{j−1} x^{jb}
= ∑_{m≥1} (∑_{b∈A, b|m} (−1)^{m/b−1}) x^m
= ∑_{m≥1} τ_A^s(m) x^m.
Combining with (c) and Cauchy product,
N_A^q(n) = [x^n] (∑_{k≥0} q_A(k) x^k)(∑_{m≥1} τ_A^s(m) x^m)
= ∑_{k=0}^{n} q_A(k) τ_A^s(n−k) = ∑_{k=0}^{n−1} q_A(k) τ_A^s(n−k),
since τ_A^s(0)=0. This proves (d).

All four
